title: How to Wash a Fleece Jacket

steps.title: Wash your fleece jacket after 6-7 wears.
steps.content: Wash your fleece jacket after 6-7 wears. You can wear your fleece several times without washing it, as the fabric is durable and tough against stains. [1] X Research source If you over-wash your fleece, the fabric may start to pill. In addition, clean your jacket whenever it is noticeably dirty. For example, if you’ve gone on a hiking trip and got very muddy, wash your jacket as soon as you get home.

steps.title: Use the washing machine if you want a fast and easy method.
steps.content: Use the washing machine if you want a fast and easy method. You can easily wash your fleece jacket in your washing machine. If you do this, be sure to wash your jacket with similar colors. If possible, wash it with other fleece clothing. [2] X Research source Avoid washing your jacket with other items that may cause lint, such as towels and washcloths. You can wash it in the washer on the delicate cycle. Use a small amount of toxin-free natural detergent. If you want to remove static electricity, you can use wool dryer balls during the dryer cycle.

steps.title: Wash your fleece jacket by hand to avoid any fabric pilling.
steps.content: Wash your fleece jacket by hand to avoid any fabric pilling. Do this if your tag recommends it or if you want to avoid any pilling on your jacket. Some particular fleece jackets require hand-washing because of their fabric of any dyes used. While washing your fleece by hand takes a bit more work, it is still easy to do. [3] X Research source While using a cold water setting with a washing machine often avoids pilling, the machine can cause the fabric to pill over time.

steps.title: Turn the jacket inside out before you wash it.
steps.content: Turn the jacket inside out before you wash it. Flip the neck of your jacket inside, pull the sleeves into the main body, and turn it inside out. This way, the outer fleece stays protected as you wash it. [4] X Research source In addition, ensure there is nothing in the pockets of your jacket before you wash it. If you leave paper in the pockets, your jacket will get covered in lint, which is almost impossible to remove. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Use mild soap powder rather than liquid detergent.
steps.content: Use mild soap powder rather than liquid detergent. To keep your fleece soft and water-resistant, purchase mild powdered detergent and review the instructions on the package regarding how much to use. For a small load, use around 5 ounces (141.8 g). [6] X Research source Liquid detergent contains chemicals that strip away the waterproof coating on your fleece jacket.

steps.title: Use the lowest temperature setting to avoid damaging your jacket.
steps.content: Use the lowest temperature setting to avoid damaging your jacket. Turn your wash temperature to the “cold” setting before you start the load. [7] X Research source If you use a warm wash setting, your fabric may start to pill. If you use a hot wash setting, the fabric may melt.

steps.title: Mix the mild powder detergent with some water to prevent soap residue.
steps.content: Mix the mild powder detergent with some water to prevent soap residue. Pour your powdered detergent into a small bowl, and add 5-10 drops of water to the bowl. Mix it up with a spoon to liquefy your detergent. This helps prevent cut down on extra soap residue when you wash your jacket. [8] X Research source If you place the powdered detergent directly into the washing machine, it may be too concentrated and result in a lot of soap residue.

steps.title: Add baking soda to your detergent mixture if your fleece smells funky.
steps.content: Add baking soda to your detergent mixture if your fleece smells funky. If you notice an odd odor on your jacket, use baking soda along with your detergent to get rid of the smell. Mix about 2-4 tbsp (29.6 - 59.2 g) into your detergent mixture before pouring it into the washing machine. [9] X Research source Baking soda is known to absorb unpleasant odors and works great when washing clothing.

steps.title: Pour your detergent mixture into the machine and start your wash cycle.
steps.content: Pour your detergent mixture into the machine and start your wash cycle. Press the “Start” button after you add your detergent. Then, come back after your wash cycle is completed. Most machines take 45-60 minutes to wash your clothing. [10] X Research source If you are washing your fleece by itself or with a few items, use a light wash cycle. If you are washing a full load of laundry, use a larger wash cycle, based on the options listed on your particular machine.

steps.title: Hang the jacket on a hanger and let it air dry.
steps.content: Hang the jacket on a hanger and let it air dry. After your clothes are washed, open up your washing machine and pull out your fleece jacket. Place the jacket on a hanger and zip it up. Leave the jacket in a dry place for 1-2 hours so it can air dry. [11] X Research source Avoid using the dryer when washing your fleece jacket. Even a light heat cycle can cause your fleece to pill, and the heat can damage your jacket. If you washed other clothing with your fleece, you can put them in the dryer.

steps.title: Fill a bucket or your sink mostly full of cold water.
steps.content: Fill a bucket or your sink mostly full of cold water. Use cool water from your faucet, and fill your bucket about two thirds of the way full so your jacket can completely soak. [12] X Research source You can also use a large plastic bin.

steps.title: Mix your powder detergent in cold water thoroughly.
steps.content: Mix your powder detergent in cold water thoroughly. When washing only 1 item of clothing, you only need a small amount of detergent. Be sure to read over the directions on your detergent packaging. Typically, you can use about 2 oz (56.7 g) of powdered detergent for your jacket. Pour this into the bucket or sink, and mix it around using a spoon. [13] X Research source Mix up the detergent as best as you can to avoid any extra soap residue.

steps.title: Soak your jacket in the soap concoction and scrub it with a brush.
steps.content: Soak your jacket in the soap concoction and scrub it with a brush. Place your fleece jacket into the bucket or sink, and submerge it entirely in the water. Locate a soft scrub brush, and move it in small, circular movements on your jacket to lift up any dirt and debris. You can work in 2–4 in (5.1–10.2 cm) areas for best results. [14] X Research source Scrub each side of your jacket for a thorough clean.

steps.title: Rinse your fleece in cool water to remove dirt, debris, and soap.
steps.content: Rinse your fleece in cool water to remove dirt, debris, and soap. Once you’re finished scrubbing your jacket, pull it out of the water and hold it underneath of cool running water. Rinse your jacket thoroughly to get rid of dirt and soap residue. [15] X Research source Your jacket is rinsed completely when you no longer see soap bubbles dripping off.

steps.title: Empty your sink or bucket after you take out the jacket.
steps.content: Empty your sink or bucket after you take out the jacket. Pour the water mixture down your drain, and rinse out your bucket with clean cool water. Continue cleaning your bucket until all soap residue is gone. [16] X Research source If you don’t clean your bucket or sink right away, the soap residue will stick on and be more difficult to remove down the line.

steps.title: Let your jacket air dry to avoid any fabric pilling.
steps.content: Let your jacket air dry to avoid any fabric pilling. Wring out any extra water, and place your jacket on a hanger. Then, hang it up in a dry place, like your bedroom or bathroom. [17] X Research source Your jacket should dry in 1-2 hours.
